paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Whether intratumoral mRNA vaccination can induce an interferon-rich tumor state that increases sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Pooled across repeat experiments to evaluate intratumoral mRNA vaccine plus anti-PD-L1 treatment efficacy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched controls including vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle conditions for comparison with combination treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective analysis of metastatic patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of retrospective cohort with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination before or around ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of retrospective cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination used for survival comparison.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
